Content.description: Requirements related to the substantive content of the articles.

requirements.description: An article should start with a clear definition in the lead section.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is.

requirements.description: For genes/proteins with a human ortholog, the lead should specify the protein and gene.
requirements.reference: "For genes/proteins in which a human ortholog exists, 'recommended UniProt name' is a protein that in humans is encoded by the 'approved HUGO gene symbol' gene."
requirements.when: Applicable for gene/protein articles with human orthologs.

requirements.description: Articles about related proteins may be cross linked by including one or more navigation boxes.
requirements.reference: Articles about related proteins may be cross linked by including one or more [[WP:NAVBOX|navigation boxes]] as appropriate.
requirements.when: When articles are about related proteins.

requirements.description: List diseases or conditions that are a result of a mutation in the gene or a deficiency or excess of the expressed protein.
requirements.reference: List diseases or conditions that are a result of a mutation in the gene or a deficiency or excess of the expressed protein.

requirements.description: Do not mention the research group or institution directly in the text of the article.
requirements.reference: In general, it is not appropriate to mention the research group or institution that conducted a study directly in the text of the article.

requirements.description: List the names of those who made key discoveries concerning the gene or protein.
requirements.reference: However it is appropriate to list the names of those who made key discoveries concerning the gene or protein in this section (e.g., the scientist or group that originally cloned the gene, determined its function, linked it to a disease, won a major award for the discovery, etc.).

requirements.description: Gene and protein articles should be categorized appropriately.
requirements.reference: Categories or subcategories that may be appropriate for gene and protein articles include: [[:Category:Proteins]], [[:Category:Enzymes by function]], [[:Category:Genes by human chromosome]].
requirements.when: Applicable to gene and protein articles.

requirements.description: Specific information about the gene should be included, such as its location on the human chromosome and regulation.
requirements.reference: Specific information about the gene (on which human chromosome it is located, regulation, etc.).

requirements.description: Basic information already contained in the infobox should not be unnecessarily repeated in the content section unless especially notable.
requirements.reference: Much of this basic information may already contained in the infobox and should not be unnecessarily repeated in this section unless especially notable.
requirements.when: Applicable when information is already in the infobox.

requirements.description: The scope of a gene/protein article should include the human gene/protein and orthologs in other species.
requirements.reference: The scope of a gene/protein article is the human gene/protein (including all splice variants derived from that gene) as well as orthologs (as listed in HomoloGene) that exist in other species.

requirements.description: If there are paralogs in humans, a gene family article should be created in addition to gene-specific articles.
requirements.reference: If there are paralogs in humans (and by extension other species), then a gene family article in addition to the gene specific articles would be appropriate.

requirements.description: Do not hype a study by listing the names, credentials, institutions, or other qualifications of their authors.
requirements.reference: In general, do not hype a study by listing the names, credentials, institutions, or other "qualifications" of their authors.

requirements.description: Article prose should focus on what a cited study says about the structure, function, clinical significance, etc. of the gene or protein.
requirements.reference: Article prose should focus on what a cited study says about the structure, function, clinical significance, etc. of the gene or protein.

requirements.description: Notable contributions and who made the discovery should be mentioned in the discovery/history section.
requirements.reference: Particularly notable contributions along with who made the discovery however should be mentioned in the discovery/history section.

requirements.description: An article should start with a clear definition in the lead section.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is.

requirements.description: Describe the function of the transcribed protein.
requirements.reference: Describe the function of the transcribed protein.

requirements.description: An article should start with a clear definition in the lead section.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is.

requirements.description: The 'Interactions' section should list proteins that the subject protein is known to interact with.
requirements.reference: Optional section that lists proteins that the protein that is the subject of the article is known to interact with.
requirements.when: Applicable when interaction data is available.

requirements.description: Use the recommended UniProt protein name as the article name if it is relatively short.
requirements.reference: If relatively short, the recommended UniProt protein name should be used as the article name.
requirements.when: Applicable when the UniProt protein name is short.

requirements.description: Use a widely used protein acronym or the official HUGO gene symbol if the protein name is verbose.
requirements.reference: If the protein name is verbose, either a widely used protein acronym or the official HUGO gene symbol, followed by '(gene)' if necessary to disambiguate.
requirements.when: Applicable when the protein name is verbose.

requirements.description: Enumerate different members of a protein family with a dash followed by an Arabic number.
requirements.reference: The different members should be enumerated with a dash '-' followed by an Arabic number, e.g. 'desmoglein-1', 'desmoglein-2', etc.
requirements.when: Applicable for proteins grouped into a family based on homology or shared function.

requirements.description: Include the taxon in the title for viral protein articles.
requirements.reference: If the article is about a viral protein, it is recommended to include the taxon in the title.
requirements.when: Applicable for articles about viral proteins.

requirements.description: A parenthesized term added to disambiguate common symbols does not constitute unnecessary disambiguation.
requirements.reference: A parenthesized term added to disambiguate common symbols does not constitute unnecessary disambiguation even when it is the only article with such a name.

requirements.description: Specific information about the protein should not be unnecessarily repeated unless especially notable.
requirements.reference: Specific information about the protein (splice variants, post translational modifications, etc.). Again, much of this basic information may already contained in the infobox and should not be unnecessarily repeated unless especially notable.

requirements.description: An article should start with a clear definition in the lead section.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is.

requirements.description: The article should provide a comprehensive overview of the gene or protein.
requirements.reference: The article should provide a comprehensive overview of the gene or protein, including its function, structure, and significance.

requirements.description: Optional section that concisely describes species, tissue, and subcellular distribution of the gene.
requirements.reference: Optional section that concisely describes what species this gene is expressed (e.g., wide species distribution, bacteria, fungi, vertebrates, mammals, etc.), what tissue the protein is expressed, and which subcellular compartments or organelles the protein is found (excreted, cytoplasm, nucleus, mitochondria, cell membrane).
requirements.where: Species, tissue, and subcellular distribution section

requirements.description: An article should start with a clear definition in the lead section.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is.

requirements.description: The lead section should summarize the most important points of the article.
requirements.reference: The lead should summarize the most important points, including the subject's significance, and establish context.

requirements.description: Articles should be written in a neutral point of view.
requirements.reference: All Wikipedia articles and other encyclopedic content must be written from a neutral point of view.

requirements.description: Avoid using jargon and technical terms without explanation.
requirements.reference: Avoid using jargon and technical terms without explanation, as Wikipedia is for a general audience.
requirements.when: Applicable when technical terms are used.

requirements.description: Ensure that all statements are verifiable with reliable sources.
requirements.reference: All material in Wikipedia mainspace, including everything in articles, lists, and captions, must be verifiable.

requirements.description: The Wikipedia article should be linked to a Wikidata item of the entity first mentioned in the first sentence of the lead section.
requirements.reference: The Wikipedia article should be linked to a Wikidata item of the entity first mentioned in the first sentence of the lead section, which should be written as defined in [[WP:MCBMOSSECTIONS]].

requirements.description: An article should start with a clear definition in the lead section.
requirements.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is.

requirements.description: The lead section should summarize the most important points of the article.
requirements.reference: The lead should summarize the most important points of the article.

requirements.description: The article should provide context for the topic.
requirements.reference: Provide context for the topic so that it is understandable to a general audience.

Language Usage.description: Guidelines for the appropriate use of language, including gene nomenclature and abbreviations.

requirements.description: Gene abbreviations should be according to HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee guidelines and written in italic font style.
requirements.reference: The abbreviations of genes are according to HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee and written in italic font style.

requirements.description: It is recommended to use gene abbreviations instead of the full name.
requirements.reference: It is recommended that abbreviations instead of the full name are used.

requirements.description: Human gene names should be written in all capitals.
requirements.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example ALDOA, INS, etc.

requirements.description: For orthologs of human genes in other species, only the initial letter is capitalised.
requirements.reference: For orthologs of human genes in other species, only the initial letter is capitalised, for example mouse Aldoa, bovine Ins, etc.

requirements.description: Use 'the ALDOA gene is regulated...' or 'ALDOA is regulated...' instead of 'the gene ALDOA is regulated'.
requirements.reference: The following usages of gene symbols are recommended: 'the ALDOA gene is regulated...', 'ALDOA is regulated...', while the following is not recommended: 'the gene ALDOA is regulated' since it is redundant.

requirements.description: Use 'the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated...' for non-human genes.
requirements.reference: The following usages of gene symbols are recommended: 'the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated...'.

requirements.description: Human gene names should be written in all capitals.
requirements.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example ALDOA, INS, etc.

requirements.description: Human gene names should be written in all capitals.
requirements.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example ALDOA, INS, etc.

requirements.description: Human gene names should be written in all capitals.
requirements.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example ALDOA, INS, etc.

requirements.description: Protein names should be written with the first letter capitalized.
requirements.reference: Protein names are written with the first letter capitalized, for example Aldolase A, Insulin, etc.

requirements.description: Use American or British English consistently throughout the article.
requirements.reference: Articles should use either American or British English consistently, unless the subject has a strong national tie to a particular English-speaking nation.

requirements.description: Avoid using first-person language.
requirements.reference: First-person language should be avoided to maintain an encyclopedic tone.

requirements.description: Human gene names should be written in all capitals.
requirements.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example ALDOA, INS, etc.

requirements.description: Use scientific names in italics.
requirements.reference: Scientific names should be italicized.

Structure.description: Guidelines on how to structure the article sections.

requirements.description: Include a History/Discovery section for articles about genes or proteins.
requirements.reference: Example articles of what such an organization may look like are: [[Protein C]], [[Gonadotropin-releasing hormone]] or [[Rubisco]].

requirements.description: Every Wikipedia article should be added to at least one category.
requirements.reference: Every Wikipedia article should be added to at least one [[WP:CATEGORY|category]].

requirements.description: Articles should follow a standard structure.
requirements.reference: Articles should follow a standard structure with sections such as lead, function, and infobox.

requirements.description: Articles should follow a logical structure with clear sections.
requirements.reference: The article should be organized into sections that follow a logical order.

requirements.description: Articles should have a clear and logical structure.
requirements.reference: Articles should have a clear and logical structure, with sections and subsections used to organize content.

requirements.description: The 'See also' section should include links to related articles.
requirements.reference: The 'See also' section should include links to related articles that provide additional context or information.

requirements.description: Articles should have a clear and logical structure.
requirements.reference: Articles should be structured in a clear and logical manner.

requirements.description: Use subheadings to organize content within sections.
requirements.reference: Subheadings should be used to organize content within sections.

Images and Diagrams.description: Guidelines for the use of images and diagrams in articles.

requirements.description: Diagrams should adhere to a standard format where possible.
requirements.reference: Where possible, diagrams should keep to a standard format.

requirements.description: Suggest expansions to the standardized formatting if the diagram guide is insufficient.
requirements.reference: If the diagram guide does not give sufficient guidance on the style for the images in an article, consider suggesting expansions to the standardised formatting.

Formatting.description: Requirements related to the formatting of the articles.

requirements.description: Use italics for gene symbols.
requirements.reference: Gene symbols should be italicized.

requirements.description: Use consistent formatting for section headers.
requirements.reference: Section headers should follow a consistent format throughout the article.

requirements.description: Use the standard infobox template for gene/protein articles.
requirements.reference: Use the standard infobox template for gene/protein articles to ensure consistency.

requirements.description: Sections should be organized in a logical order.
requirements.reference: Sections should be organized in a logical order, typically starting with an introduction, followed by sections on structure, function, and clinical significance.

requirements.description: Use consistent formatting for headings and subheadings.
requirements.reference: Headings and subheadings should be used to organize content and should follow a consistent format.

requirements.description: Use bullet points for lists where appropriate.
requirements.reference: Bullet points should be used for lists where appropriate to improve readability.

requirements.description: Images should be placed in a way that enhances the text.
requirements.reference: Images should be placed in a way that enhances the text and does not disrupt the flow of reading.

requirements.description: Use consistent formatting for section headings.
requirements.reference: Section headings should be consistent in style and formatting.

requirements.description: Use bullet points for lists where appropriate.
requirements.reference: Bullet points should be used for lists where appropriate.

Citations.description: Guidelines for citing sources in the articles.

requirements.description: All statements should be supported by citations.
requirements.reference: All statements should be supported by reliable sources.

requirements.description: All statements should be supported by reliable sources.
requirements.reference: Statements in the article should be backed by citations from reliable sources.

requirements.description: All statements should be supported by reliable sources.
requirements.reference: All statements should be supported by reliable sources to ensure the accuracy and credibility of the article.

requirements.description: Use inline citations for specific claims.
requirements.reference: Use inline citations for specific claims to provide direct evidence for the information presented.
requirements.when: Applicable for specific claims and data.

requirements.description: Citations should be provided for all direct quotes.
requirements.reference: Citations must be provided for all direct quotes to ensure verifiability.
requirements.when: Applicable when direct quotes are used.

requirements.description: Use inline citations for statements that are challenged or likely to be challenged.
requirements.reference: Inline citations should be used for statements that are challenged or likely to be challenged.

requirements.description: All statements should be supported by reliable sources.
requirements.reference: Statements should be supported by reliable sources.

requirements.description: Use inline citations for direct quotes.
requirements.reference: Inline citations should be used for direct quotes.

requirements.description: MCB articles should be relatively dense with inline citations.
requirements.reference: MCB articles should be relatively dense with inline citations, using either <nowiki><ref></nowiki> tags (footnotes) or parenthetical citations.

requirements.description: It is not acceptable to write substantial amounts of prose and then add your textbook to the 'References' section as a non-specific or general reference.
requirements.reference: It is not acceptable to write substantial amounts of prose and then add your textbook to the 'References' section as a non-specific or general reference.

requirements.description: The format of citations should be consistent within any one article.
requirements.reference: There is no standard for formatting citations on Wikipedia, but the format should be consistent within any one article.

requirements.description: Some editors prefer to expand the abbreviated journal name; others prefer concise standard abbreviations.
requirements.reference: Some editors prefer to expand the abbreviated journal name; others prefer concise standard abbreviations.

requirements.description: Abstracts of most MCB related journals are freely available at PubMed.
requirements.reference: Abstracts of most MCB related journals are freely available at PubMed, which includes a means of searching the MEDLINE database.

requirements.description: The easiest way to populate the journal and book citation templates is to use Diberri's template-filling web site or the Universal reference formatter.
requirements.reference: The easiest way to populate the journal and book citation templates is to use Diberri's template-filling web site or the Universal reference formatter.

requirements.description: Multiple references to the same source citation can be achieved by ensuring the inline reference is named uniquely.
requirements.reference: Multiple references to the same source citation can be achieved by ensuring the inline reference is named uniquely.
requirements.when: When citing the same source multiple times.

requirements.description: In addition to the standard citation text, it is useful to supply hyperlinks.
requirements.reference: In addition to the standard citation text, it is useful to supply hyperlinks.

requirements.description: If the journal abstract is available on PubMed, add a link by typing PMID xxxxxxxxx.
requirements.reference: If the journal abstract is available on PubMed, add a link by typing PMID xxxxxxxxx.
requirements.when: When citing journal abstracts available on PubMed.

requirements.description: If the article has a DOI, use the doi template.
requirements.reference: If the article has a DOI, use the doi template.

requirements.description: If the article's full text is freely available online, supply a URL to this text by hyperlinking the article title in the citation.
requirements.reference: If and only if the article's full text is freely available online, supply a URL to this text by hyperlinking the article title in the citation.
requirements.when: When the full text is freely available online.

requirements.description: When the source text is available in both HTML and PDF, the former should be preferred.
requirements.reference: When the source text is available in both HTML and PDF, the former should be preferred as it is compatible with a larger range of browsers.

requirements.description: Do not add a 'Retrieved on' date for convenience links to online editions of paper journals.
requirements.reference: Do not add a 'Retrieved on' date for convenience links to online editions of paper journals.
requirements.when: When citing online editions of paper journals.

requirements.description: Use citation templates such as Cite journal, Cite book, Cite web, Cite press release, and Cite news.
requirements.reference: Others prefer to use citation templates such as Cite journal, Cite book, Cite web, Cite press release and Cite news.

requirements.description: Citations in the Vancouver format can be produced using the vauthors or veditors parameters.
requirements.reference: Citations in the Vancouver format can be produced using the vauthors or veditors parameters.

requirements.description: The Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals citation guidelines list up to six authors, followed by 'et al.' if there are more than six.
requirements.reference: The Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals citation guidelines list up to six authors, followed by 'et al.' if there are more than six.
requirements.when: When citing sources with more than six authors.

Infoboxes.description: Guidelines for the use of infoboxes in articles.

requirements.description: Include an infobox for gene/protein articles.
requirements.reference: An infobox should be included for gene/protein articles.

requirements.description: Infoboxes should be used to summarize key facts about the subject.
requirements.reference: Infoboxes should be used to summarize key facts about the subject in a consistent format.
requirements.when: Applicable when an infobox is relevant.

requirements.description: Include one or more appropriate infoboxes at the top of each article.
requirements.reference: One or more of the following infoboxes as appropriate should be included at the top of each article.

requirements.description: Use the Infobox GNF protein for genes/proteins with a human ortholog.
requirements.reference: Infobox GNF protein: for genes/proteins for which an ortholog is present within the human genome.
requirements.when: Applicable when an ortholog is present within the human genome.

requirements.description: Use the Infobox protein for protein family articles discussing more than one protein.
requirements.reference: Infobox protein: smaller box appropriate for protein family articles where more than one protein is discussed.

requirements.description: Use the Infobox nonhuman protein for proteins without a human ortholog.
requirements.reference: Infobox nonhuman protein: for proteins without a human ortholog.
requirements.when: Applicable for proteins without a human ortholog.

requirements.description: Use the Infobox protein family for protein families listed in Pfam.
requirements.reference: Infobox protein family: for protein families that are listed in Pfam.
requirements.when: Applicable for protein families listed in Pfam.

requirements.description: Use the Infobox rfam for RNA families listed in Rfam.
requirements.reference: Infobox rfam: for RNA families that are listed in Rfam.
requirements.when: Applicable for RNA families listed in Rfam.

requirements.description: Use the Infobox enzyme for enzymes based on EC number.
requirements.reference: Infobox enzyme: for enzymes based on EC number.
requirements.when: Applicable for enzymes based on EC number.

requirements.description: Add a corresponding enzyme infobox if there is only one human paralog assigned to an EC number.
requirements.reference: If there is only one human paralog assigned to a given EC number, then in addition to a protein infobox, it may be appropriate to also add the corresponding enzyme infobox.
requirements.when: Applicable when there is only one human paralog assigned to an EC number.

requirements.description: Include a protein family infobox if there is only one human paralog assigned to a Pfam family.
requirements.reference: If there is only one human paralog that has been assigned to Pfam family, then including a protein family infobox may also be appropriate.
requirements.when: Applicable when there is only one human paralog assigned to a Pfam family.

requirements.description: Place less useful infoboxes in a section at the end if a large number of infoboxes apply.
requirements.reference: There exist some cases where a large number of infoboxes may apply to an article. You may put less useful ones in a section at the end, laid side-by-side with a table.
requirements.when: Applicable when a large number of infoboxes apply.

requirements.description: Avoid collapsing or horizontally scrolling infobox tables unless necessary.
requirements.reference: Collapsing or horizontally scrolling the said table is doubtful, as MOS:COLLAPSE may or may not apply depending on how 'extraneous' the boxes are.
requirements.when: Applicable when considering the layout of infoboxes.
